skill.name: skill-permissions
skill.description: Skill permission analysis, one-time authorization, analyze skill permissions, batch authorization
skill.summary: Skill permission analysis, one-time authorization, analyze skill permissions, batch authorization
skill.author: guo-yu

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate security utility skill for Claude Code. All 407 static findings are false positives - they document dangerous command patterns that the skill explicitly BLOCKS from authorization. The skill performs read-only analysis of skill permissions and generates safe authorization rules. Documentation includes defensive warnings about risky operations like rm, sudo, and curl|bash patterns.

content.value_statement: Claude Code skills require permissions to access files and run commands. This skill automatically analyzes what permissions each skill needs and generates safe authorization rules. It identifies dangerous patterns like recursive delete and privilege escalation, blocking them from authorization.
actual_capabilities: Scan all installed skills to identify required permissions
Analyze SKILL.md files to extract bash command patterns
Generate safe permission rules with wildcards
Block dangerous commands like rm, sudo, and curl|bash
Execute one-time authorizations for specific or all skills
Inject allow commands into skill documentation
limitations: Cannot modify skill source code, only documentation files
Requires existing skills with SKILL.md files to analyze
Cannot remove permissions, only add new ones
Permission changes require new session or /clear to take effect

use_cases.title: Quick permission setup
use_cases.description: Run /skill-permissions allow-all to authorize all installed skills at once for immediate productivity.

use_cases.title: Permission auditing
use_cases.description: Analyze specific skills to understand exactly what commands they can run before authorizing.

use_cases.title: Permission documentation
use_cases.description: Use inject command to add authorization commands to your skill documentation automatically.

output: Skill: port-allocator | Commands: find, ls, cat, lsof | Status: Unauthorized
Skill: share-skill | Commands: find, mv, ln, git | Status: Unauthorized
Users can now run /<skill-name> allow directly

best_practices: Run /skill-permissions first to review analysis before running allow commands
Use explicit allow commands like /skill-permissions allow port-allocator instead of allow-all
Review generated permission rules to understand what commands each skill can run
Use /clear after authorizing to apply permissions immediately
anti_patterns: Running /skill-permissions allow-all without reviewing what permissions are granted
Using /skill-permissions inject without understanding it modifies skill documentation files
Assuming all skills need the same permissions - review each skill individually
Ignoring the blocked commands warning - the blocklist exists to protect you

faq.question: What does /skill-permissions do?
faq.answer: It analyzes all installed skills, identifies what bash commands they need, and generates safe permission rules to authorize them.

faq.question: Is it safe to run allow-all?
faq.answer: It is safe but grants permissions broadly. Review the analysis output first, and prefer explicit allow commands for specific skills when possible.

faq.question: What commands are blocked?
faq.answer: Dangerous patterns like rm, sudo, chmod 777, curl|bash, and fork bombs are blocked and will never be authorized.

faq.question: How do permissions take effect?
faq.answer: Permission changes apply in the next Claude Code session, or run /clear immediately to apply them.

faq.question: Can this skill modify my files?
faq.answer: Only the inject command modifies files (SKILL.md documentation). Analysis and allow commands only read and update ~/.claude/settings.json.

faq.question: What is the inject command?
faq.answer: It adds /<skill-name> allow documentation to each skill's SKILL.md file, letting users authorize skills directly from their documentation.
